title: Sip These Types of Tea to Ease Everyday Ailments
author: Gaby Vaca-Flores
description: Suffer from indigestion, brain fog, or skin irritation? Turns out there's a tea for that. Here are 5 types of tea and their healing benefits.
cleaned_text: THE WELLNEST [Food](https://www.humnutrition.com/blog/category/food/) [Healthy Eating](https://www.humnutrition.com/blog/category/food/healthy-eating/) Sip These Types of Tea to Ease Everyday Ailments By [Gaby Vaca-Flores, CLE](https://www.humnutrition.com/blog/author/gaby-vaca-flores/), outlines five popular types of tea and their health benefits. Herbal teas offer a range of therapeutic properties. But with so many types of tea out there, it can be challenging to boil down the list to find the right one for your concern. (See what we did there?) Follow this guide on tea benefits the next time you want to prepare a home remedy. 5 Types of Tea and Their Benefits to Ease Everyday Ailments 1. Peppermint Tea Helps with: - indigestion - nausea - headaches - seasonal allergies [validate these traditions](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/16767798). Peppermint tea provides antiviral, antioxidant, antimicrobial, and antiallergenic benefits to the body. The most common therapeutic use of peppermint tea is for digestive-related ailments like indigestion, gas, and [bloating](https://www.humnutrition.com/blog/bloating/). As per a 2002 study, peppermint tea can help [reduce digestion-related abdominal pain](https://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/full/10.1046/j.1365-2036.2002.01339.x)through muscle relaxation. This muscle-relaxing mechanism also helps [relieve headaches](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/23196150)when consumed as tea or applied topically as an [essential oil](https://www.humnutrition.com/blog/essential-oils/). (Additionally, chewing peppermint leaves is widely recognized for reducing nausea.) Lastly, [rosmarinic acid](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC3307200/)—a chemical compound found in peppermint tea—may help minimize [seasonal allergy](https://www.humnutrition.com/blog/seasonal-allergies/)symptoms like sneezing, coughing, and itchiness. Hot Tip:Indulging in a meal that may cause an [upset stomach](https://www.humnutrition.com/blog/remedies-for-upset-stomach/)? Complement it with a warm cup of peppermint tea to ease indigestion. 2. Oolong Tea Helps with: - brain fog - skin irritation related to [eczema](https://www.humnutrition.com/blog/eczema/)and dermatitis [improved memory](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/20617284)and processed information at a much higher rate than their non-tea drinking counterparts. Next, oolong tea is saturated with beneficial polyphenols and antioxidants. As a result, drinking oolong tea can ease skin irritation caused by eczema and dermatitis. A 2001 study found that participants with atopic dermatitis who drank oolong tea showed [moderate skin improvement](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/11176659)in as little as two weeks. Hot Tip:Drinking a cup of oolong tea may help you stay sharp before an important exam. 3. Green Tea Helps with: - skin irritation - wound healing [medicinal properties of green tea](https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/abs/pii/S0024320505012415#bb0405)are attributed to its blend of polyphenols, flavonoids, and caffeine. Eastern medicine uses green tea as a [topical remedy](https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S096399690900012X#bibins2)for swelling, burns, and wounds. Research indicates that the polyphenolic component of green tea [promotes skin regeneration](https://jpet.aspetjournals.org/content/306/1/29). In short, green tea may help heal burns and wounds faster. The antiseptic properties of green tea can also help calm the skin from bug bites and other rashes. HOT Tip:Going on a hike or [camping trip](https://www.humnutrition.com/blog/benefits-of-spending-time-in-nature/)? Pack a few teabags of your favorite unsweetened green tea. If an insect bites you, soak the teabags in water and apply the compresses to the irritated area. 4. Lemon Balm Tea Helps with: - cold sores - insomnia ["modulator of mood and cognitive function."](https://www.mdpi.com/2072-6643/6/11/4805)Simply put, a warm cup of lemon balm tea may actually help you feel happier. Additionally, it can help you become more resilient to stress and avoid consequential ailments. Furthermore, lemon balm has an [anti-herpetic effect](https://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/full/10.1002/ptr.5166). Cold sores—a strain of the herpes simplex virus (HSV)—may flare up when you're overwhelmed. By helping to ease your stress response, lemon balm tea may reduce the incidence of stress-induced flareups. Similar to peppermint, lemon balm contains antiviral properties thanks to rosmarinic acid, its superhero phenolic compound. Lastly, lemon balm tea's anxiolytic (anti-stress) properties also make it the perfect drink to combat insomnia. [Evidence-based findings](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC3230760/)show that lemon balm tea extract may help with [sleep disturbances](https://www.humnutrition.com/blog/alcohol-and-sleep/)and overall stress reduction. Hot Tip:Brew lemon balm tea to help prevent stress-related ailments. 5. Ginger Tea Helps with: - the common cold - PMS-related symptoms [remedy during cold season](https://www.humnutrition.com/blog/how-to-stop-a-cold/)or when that time of the month rolls around. Ginger is a safe, natural alternative to medicine. It helps fight the common cold due to its anti-inflammatory properties. Ginger consists of two anti-inflammatory compounds—6-gingerol and gingerdiones—that work together to relieve pain. This calming effect extends to [monthly menstrual pain](https://www.humnutrition.com/blog/what-causes-period-pain/). In fact, a 2014 study shows that ginger tea is [just as effective](https://www.hindawi.com/journals/isrn/2014/792708/)as the leading OTC pain medicine in relieving PMS pain. Hot Tip:Keep ginger tea on hand when the first signs of the common cold and PMS pains kick in. Remember, you can use different types of tea to naturally ease everyday ailments. However, you should always check with your doctor before starting a new treatment plan, modifying your medication routine, or if symptoms worsen. More like this
